cat:name.gco:CharacterString: Feature Catalog for the Landscape-Level Ecological Assessment and Inventory database (LLEIAdb)

cat:scope.gco:CharacterString: LLEIA is a compilation database that sources data from several distinct collection sources, where each data source is housed in its own schema. The schemas available within this database are 1) The Natural Resource Inventory (NRI) Grazing Land schema, also known as Landscape Monitoring Framework (LMF) schema, 2) The U.S. Dept. of Agriculture (USDA) Agricultural Research Service (ARS) Jornada Experimental Range's Database for Inventory, Monitoring, and Assessment (DIMA) 3) LLEIA's own custom schema for plant/soil ecological monitoring data. Metadata for DIMA and LMF schemas are not provided as those schemas are not maintained by the author. LLEIA's custom schema (eco) tables are documented. Data from the other two schema's are converted to the LLEIA schema through the use of materialized views and can be found in the public schema.

cit:name.gco:CharacterString: Stringham Range Ecology Lab. University of Nevada, Reno.

gfc:definition.gco:CharacterString: Info on individual data sets imported into the database.
A unique alphanumeric string identifier for the source database
The path at which the source database was located during import.
A description of the data source or the type/location/time of data collected.

The md5hash of the source database during import. For fileGDBs, the hash of the individual file hashes, minus the a00000004.gdbtable and a00000004.gdbtablx, a00000004.freelist, timestamps, and any lock files.
Table for recording disturbance sources/types observed during field collection.

A unique alphanumeric string identifier for the plot. LMF source: POINT - concatenation of STATE, COUNTY, and PSU in that order. DIMA source: tblPlot - PlotKey. UNR source: a concatenation of the date field (YYYYMMDD) the MLRA and a three digit number (000 to 999).

The date of the survey of the plot, in this case also the establishment date. LMF source: POINTCOORDINATES - CAPDATE (UTC time). DIMA source: tblPlots - EstablishDate (local time). UNR source: Date (local time).
LMF source: Same. This field integrates where the disturbance indicators are and when the disturbance occurred. DIMA source: 'NA'. UNR source: 'NA'.
Disturbance is in the general area of the plot and has occurred over one year ago.
Disturbance is in the general area of the plot and had occurred within the last year.
Disturbance is within the plot and has occurred over one year ago.
Disturbance is within the plot and and had occurred within the last year.
Spatial and temporal data about the disturbance was not recorded.
Cultivation (plowing, discing, cultivator, chisel plow etc.).
Whether or not the plot or the area around the plot has been hayed.
Mowing (clipping).
Hay removal.
Soil disturbance from heavy machinery.
Seedbed preparation (tillage implements, drill).
Livestock tanks, spring development.
Livestock heavy use area.
Livestock grazing.
Degree of grazing use of the management unit containing the plot.
Currently grazed light (less than 30% harvest)
Currently grazed moderate (30-50% harvest)
Currently grazed heavy (greater than 50% harvest)
Insects.
Rodents.
Non-rodent animals.
Wildlife grazing impacts.
Mining/Energy/equip. and operations.
Recreation (trails, foot traffic).
Recreation (vehicles, bikes).
Livestock walkway, trailing.
Roads/Lanes (dirt).
Roads/lanes (gravel).
Roads/lanes (paved).
Drainage or field ditch.
Underground utilities.
Overhead transmission.
Construction activities (fence, pipeline, terraces etc.).
Water, flooding/ponding.
Soil deposition caused by water.
Soil deposition caused by wind.
Water erosion.
Wind erosion.
Transported fill material.
Wildfire.
Prescribed fire.
Fire fighting (machinery, clearing).
Brush control (chemical).
Brush control (mechanical).
Brush mgt. biological treatment.
Other disturbances not captured in other fields.
A description of the disturbance(s) if other disturbance = True.
Any notes about disturbances on the plot.
Data about NRCS ecological site(s) identified within a plot during a method collection instance.
A unique alphanumeric string identifier for the method collection instance.

The identifier of a particular ecological community found within the plot without the site type prepended (F,R,G). For NRCS ecological sites, it is a concatenation of NRCS Major Land Resource Area (MLRA) symbol, Land Resource Unit(LRU) symbol, site number and state FIPS alpha code.
A single character which identifies the NRCS ecological site type.
Rangeland ecological site.
Forested ecological site.
Grassland ecological site.
The name of the identified ecological site found within the plot.
The estimated percentage of the plot area made up of the ecological site (0, 1]
The rank of the ecosite in terms of percent area, with 1 being the most dominant rank.

The ecological state that the ecosite is in at the the time of method collection according to the State and Transition Diagram found within the NRCS Ecological Site Description for the observed ecosite. Preferably given in the form of {state_number}, {state_label} (e.g. '6, Tree State').

The specific community phase within the ecological state that the plot is in at the the time of method collection according to the State and Transition Diagram found within the Ecological Site Description for the observed ecosite. Preferably given in the form of {state_number.community_number, community label} (e.g. '2.1, At Risk').
A description of the specific community phase given in state_community, including factors that influenced the specific community phase designation.
NRCS ecological sites found within a plot whose boundaries have been collected at the transect level.
A unique alphanumeric string identifier for the transect on which the data were collected.
A unique alphanumeric string identifier for the method collection instance.
The sequence order along the transect at which point the ecological site was encountered.

The identifier of a particular ecological community found within the plot without the site type prepended (F,R,G). For NRCS ecological sites, it is a concatenation of NRCS Major Land Resource Area (MLRA) symbol, Land Resource Unit(LRU) symbol, site number and state FIPS alpha code.
Mark on the transect that the ecological site begins. Units are in transect.transect_units.
Mark on the transect where the ecological site ends. Units are in transect.transect_units.
Data about the Ecological Site Functional Structural Groups method collection instance.
A unique alphanumeric string identifier for the method collection instance.
The date and time of the method collection instance.
The (preferably) full name(s) or initials of the person measuring for the collection instance.
Any notes collected about the method collection instance that are particular to the method collection itself.
A unique alphanumeric string identifier for the plot at which the data were collected.
Long form note records for the plot.
A unique alphanumeric string identifier for the method collection instance.
The date and time the note was recorded.
The "section" that the note corresponds to (e.g., soils, line-point intercept).
Note associated with the LMF Standing Biomass protocol.
Note associated with the LMF Resource Concerns protocol.
Note associated with the LMF Disturbance Indicators protocol.
Note associated with the LMF Ecological Site/Forage Suitability Group Transect Information and Use protocol.

gfc:sourceIdentifier.gco:CharacterString: Chapter 8. Ecological Site/Forage Suitability Transect Information and Use, p. 46.

gfc:definition.gco:CharacterString: Note associated with the LMF Point Location and Plot/Transect Layout protocol. Specifically referring to notes about position data.

gfc:sourceIdentifier.gco:CharacterString: Chapter 3. Point Location and Plot/Transect Layout, p. 10.

gfc:definition.gco:CharacterString: Note associated with the LMF Point Location and Plot/Transect Layout protocol. Specifically referring to notes about site access/accessibility.

gfc:sourceIdentifier.gco:CharacterString: Chapter 3. Point Location and Plot/Transect Layout, p. 10.

gfc:definition.gco:CharacterString: Note associated with the LMF Land Cover/Use protocol.
Note associated with the LMF Gap Intercept: Basal and Canopy Gaps protocol.

gfc:sourceIdentifier.gco:CharacterString: Chapter 10. Gap Intercept: Basal and Canopy Gaps, p. 59.

gfc:definition.gco:CharacterString: General notes about the plot.
Note associated with the LMF Plant Height protocol.
Note associated with LMF protocol practice.
Note associated with the LMF Species Composition by Weight protocol (Non-Federal Rangeland Only).

gfc:sourceIdentifier.gco:CharacterString: Chapter 14. Species Composition by Weight, p. 82.

gfc:definition.gco:CharacterString: Note associated with the LMF Line Point Transects for Cover Composition protocol.

gfc:sourceIdentifier.gco:CharacterString: Chapter 9. Line Point Transects for Cover Composition, p. 52.

gfc:definition.gco:CharacterString: Note associated with the LMF Rangeland Health protocol (Rangeland only).
Note associated with the LMF Sagebrush Shape protocol (Rangeland only).
Note associated with the LMF Landscape and Soils protocol.
Note associated with the LMF Soil Stability Test protocol.

Note associated with the LMF Plant Census protocol, specifically in relation to an unknown/unidentified plant. This a generalized value pertaining to a set of values all starting with 'unknownPlant2' and ending with a USDA Unknown Plant Code and a sequence number (e.g. 1, 2, 3, etc.).
Long form note.
A unique alphanumeric string identifier for the plot at which the data were collected.
Detail records associated with the line-point intercept method which includes plant cover, height, and decadence measurements.
A unique site identifier for each method collection instance.
This refers to the point along the transect in units of that transect (See transect.transect_units).
An integer designating the layer order of the vegetation layer hit, with 1 being the topmost (tallest) layer.
A code abbreviation designating if the hit was a layer hit or nearby vegetation selected by growth habit.
Layer hit. The hit is part of the vertical structure cross-sectioned by the measuring device (pin, laser, etc.). These are the only type of hits that can be used to measure point-intercept cover

Growth habit hit. The hit is not from the vertical cross sectional area but is chosen from nearby vegetation according to methodology parameters, generally for the purpose of measuring height. These types of hits cannot be used to measure point-intercept cover.
A code abbreviation designating what category a hit falls under.
Top. The hit is part of the cross sectional layer and is the top hit.
Lower. The hit is part of the cross sectional layer and is neither the top or surface hit.
Surface. The hit is part of the cross sectional layer and is the lowest hit (i.e. surface or basal).
Herbaceous. The hit is not part of the cross sectional layer and falls within herbaceous criteria.
Woody. The hit is not part of the cross sectional layer and falls within woody criteria.
A code referring to the vegetation layer "hit" for a hit order at a mark.
The plant height, in centimeters for a hit order at a mark.
A boolean flag which indicates whether the portion of vegetation layer hit is dead.
Data about the line-point intercept method collection instance.
A unique alphanumeric string identifier for the method collection instance.
The date of the survey of the plot. LMF source: POINTCOORDINATES - CAPDATE (UTC time). DIMA source: tblLPIHeader - FormDate (local time). UNR source: Date (local time).
The (preferably) full name(s) or initials of the person measuring for the collection instance.
Any notes collected about the method collection instance that are particular to the method collection itself.
A unique alphanumeric string identifier for the transect on which the data were collected.
Records of plants found during the plant census collection instance.
A unique alphanumeric string identifier for the method collection instance.
The order that a species was documented during the census.
The NRCS plant code of a plant species.
Any notes about a specific species, such as identifying characteristics in that case that the code is an unknown code.
Data about the plant census collection instance. Check methodology documentation for time searched.
A unique alphanumeric string identifier for the method collection instance.
The date and time of the method collection instance.
The (preferably) full name(s) or initials of the person measuring for the collection instance.
The size of the plot on which the method was conducted in square meters.
Any notes collected about the method collection instance that are particular to the method collection itself.
A unique alphanumeric string identifier for the plot at which the data were collected.
Data for a single plot/point and its establishment protocol(s).
A unique alphanumeric string identifier for the plot at which the data were collected.
A label/identifier for the plot.
The survey year for which the plot was generated as part of a survey panel.
The date of the establishment of the plot.
The Current state Federal Information Processing Series (FIPS) code for the state where the plot is located.

gfc:label.gco:CharacterString: National Standard Codes (ANSI INCITS 38-2009), Federal Information Processing Series (FIPS) - States/State Equivalents

gfc:definition.gco:CharacterString: The Current county Federal Information Processing Series (FIPS) code for the county where the plot is located.

gfc:label.gco:CharacterString: National Standard Codes (ANSI INCITS 31-2009), Federal Information Processing Series (FIPS) - Counties/County Equivalents

gfc:definition.gco:CharacterString: The symbol identifier for an NRCS Major Land Resource Area that the plot falls geographically within.
Three character abbreviation for the surface ownership on which the plot falls.
The primary category of the landform on which the plot primarily falls.
The secondary category of the landform on which the plot primarily falls.
The down slope shape of the plot location.
Slope Shape

cit:title.gco:CharacterString: Schoeneberger, P.J., D.A. Wysocki, E.C. Benham, and Soil Staff. 2012. Field book for describing and sampling soils, Version 3.0. Natural Resources Conservation Service, National Soil Center, Lincoln, NE

gfc:definition.gco:CharacterString: The across slope shape of the plot location.
Slope Shape
The percent slope (vertical change / horizontal change) of the plot ranging from 0 to 100.

The slope length is defined as the distance from the point of origin of overland flow to the point where either the slope gradient decreases enough that soil deposition begins or the runoff water enters a well-defined channel that may be part of a drainage network or constructed channel. Units are in transect units (See transect_transect_units).
The aspect of the slope, or the down slope direction toward which a slope faces measured using a compass, of a plot. Aspect is in degrees ranging from 0-359.
Latitude for the plot center in decimal degrees, WGS 84 datum, where negative values are for southern hemisphere.
Range Domain Minimum: -90. Range Domain Maximum: 90.
Longitude for the plot center in decimal degrees, WGS 84 datum, where negative values are for western hemisphere.
Range Domain Minimum: -180. Range Domain Maximum: 180.
Elevation for the plot center in meters.
Range Domain Minimum: -1355. Range Domain Maximum: 29029.

Indicates whether field GPS points were captured. If "successful", then the field crew was able to capture a location with GPS on their electronic data capture device; if "poor GPS", the field crew was unable to capture a GPS location using their electronic data capture device.
The full time zone name found in the IANA timezone database (See Also pg_timezone_names table).
Alphanumeric codes associated with each named Major Land Resource Area.

gfc:sourceIdentifier.gco:CharacterString: Internet Assigned Numbers Authority (IANA) Time Zone Database

cit:title.gco:CharacterString: Internet Assigned Numbers Authority. Public Technical Identifiers. Retrieved 28 May 2021 from https://www.iana.org/

gfc:definition.gco:CharacterString: latitude, longitude, elevation, and datum converted to Geography data type. Horizontal Datum: WGS 84 (srid 4326).
A unique alphanumeric string identifier for the site to which a plot belongs.
Plant biomass production data.
A unique alphanumeric string identifier for the method collection instance.
An NRCS plant species code for the plant being measured.
The subplot number in which the data are collected.

The number of units of production estimated for the plant. Units are a specific estimation weight given for each species, in grams, found in the production_species.unit_wgt_g field. E.g. Three units with a unit_wgt_g of five would have a mass of 15 grams.
A flag indicating that a species was found at a subplot, but that its production is trace.
The weight of the clipped vegetation (current year's growth), in grams for that species at a subplot (when double sampling).
Data about the annual plant biomass production method collection instance.
A unique alphanumeric string identifier for the method collection instance.
The date and time of the method collection instance.
The (preferably) full name(s) or initials of the person measuring for the collection instance.
The number of subplots used for the method collection instance.
Any notes collected about the method collection instance that are particular to the method collection itself.
A unique alphanumeric string identifier for the plot at which the data were collected.
Data about individual species measured during the annual plant biomass production method collection instance.
A unique alphanumeric string identifier for the method collection instance.
The NRCS plant code of a plant species.
The subplot size in square meters that was used for a species.

The weight in grams for a production estimation unit for a species. An estimation unit is a counted unit made up of a certain estimated mass, e.g. three units with a unit_wgt_g of five would have a mass of 15 grams.
The air dry weight adjustment factor, an adjustment which will convert green weight to air dry weight.
The utilization adjustment factor. This is the percentage of the plant remaining after livestock/wildlife grazing has occurred.
The proportion of the total expected growth that the plant has experienced this season.

The climate adjustment factor for a species, where one would be "normal" climatic conditions. Values above one would indicate climate conditions exceeded normal, opposite for those values less than one (e.g. a value of 1.2 would indicate climatic conditions producing 20% more than "normal" year.)
Data about the annual plant biomass production method collection instance.
A unique alphanumeric string identifier for the method collection instance.
The subplot number in which the data are collected.
A description of where the subplot is located within the plot.
A flag indicating that this subplot was expanded for one size to another for certain or all species.
A flag indicating that this subplot was not sampled, despite its inclusion in the design.
The Sites associated with the point/plot records.
A unique alphanumeric string identifier for the site to which a plot belongs.
The short name/label of the site.
A longer description for the site.
Any data about the ownership related to the site.
The specific source of the site data (e.g. Entity Name, Program Name, Dataset Name).
The collection database type that this site is from.
Source data is from USDA ARS Jornada's Database for Inventory, Monitoring and Assessment (DIMA) schema, or was converted to this schema before distribution.
Source data is from a Natural Resources Inventory (NRI) or Landscape Monitoring Framework (LMF) schema, or was converted to this schema before distribution.
Source data is from the native LLEIAdb schema, or was converted to this schema before distribution.
Name of the person(s) that this site is associated with (e.g. owner name, agency personel, etc.) whom can be contacted regarding this questions about the site.
Any notes that are specific to the site level.
A unique alphanumeric string identifier for the source database
Data describing the horizons of a soil.
A unique alphanumeric string identifier for the method collection instance.
A sequential number identifying each of the soil horizons described at the site. Sequence number ascends as horizon depth increases.
The depth from the soil surface to the upper break of the described soil horizon in centimeters.
The depth from the soil surface to the lower break of the described soil horizon in centimeters.
The soil taxonomic horizon designation (e.g A, Btk)
NRCS Horizon and Layer Designations Codes
The Hue of the soil (wet or dry) as determined with a Munsell Soil Color Chart. LMF source: None. DIMA source: tblSoilPitHorizons - ESD_Hue. UNR source: None.

cit:title.gco:CharacterString: Munsell Color (Firm). (2010). Munsell soil color charts : with genuine Munsell color chips. Grand Rapids, MI :Munsell Color

gfc:definition.gco:CharacterString: The Value of the soil (wet or dry) as determined with a Munsell Soil Color Chart. LMF source: None. DIMA source: tblSoilPitHorizons - ESD_Value. UNR source: None.
The Chroma of the soil (wet or dry) as determined with a Munsell Soil Color Chart. LMF source: None. DIMA source: tblSoilPitHorizons - ESD_Chroma. UNR source: None.
The moisture content of the soil when the color was measured. LMF source: None. DIMA source: tblSoilPitHorizons - LOWER(ESD_Color). UNR source: None.
NRCS Soil Moisture State Values
The percent of surface area covered in a concentration for gravel fragment classes.
Concentrations - Quantity
The NRCS pedogenic carbonate accumulation stage.
Pedogenic Carbonate Stage Description
Flag that indicates presence of clay films on peds.
Ped and Void Surface Features - Kind
The NASIS code for the soil texture of the horizon.
NRCS Texture Class Codes
NASIS Soil horizon modifier code for rock content (cobbly, etc).
NRCS Texture Modifier Codes
A flag indicating whether the soil horizon is gypic or not
NRCS Compositional Texture Modifier Codes
The percent by volume of discrete, water-stable particles greater than 2 mm.
A flag indicating whether the soil horizon is petrocalcic or not
NRCS Fragment Cementation Status
The primary structure of the soil. Structure is the naturally occurring arrangement of soil particles into aggregates that results from pedogenic processes.
NRCS Soil Structure Codes (NASIS)
The primary grade of the soil structure.
NRCS Soil Structure Grade Codes
The primary size class of the soil structure.
NRCS Soil Structure Size Codes (NASIS)
The verbage describing how the primary structure transitions to the secondary structure (e.g. 'parting to' or 'over').
NRCS Soil Structure compound description.
The secondary structure of the soil in a compund structure. Structure is the naturally occurring arrangement of soil particles into aggregates that results from pedogenic processes.
NRCS Soil Structure Codes (NASIS)
The secondary grade of the soil in a compound structure.
NRCS Soil Structure Grade Codes
The secondary size class of the soil in a compound structure.
NRCS Soil Structure Size Codes (NASIS)

LMF source: Same. Effervescence classes from a weak hydrochloric acid test. See the protocol (Chapter 7) for detailed information. Standard soils texts (e.g., Field Book for Describing and Sampling Soils) are also helpful references. This protocol was added in 2012. DIMA source: tblSoilPitHorizons - Effer. UNR source: None.
NRCS Effervescence Class Codes

Any long form note or comment pertaining to the soil horizon. LMF source: SOILHORIZON - UNUSUAL_FEATURES. This is a text field containing notes about unusual soil features. This protocol was added in 2012. DIMA source: tblSoilPitHorizons - ESD_Notes. UNR source: None.
Records storing data about the soil description methodology (stored in the soilhorizon table).

A unique identifier for each soil pit. LMF source: SOILHORIZON - Concatenation of the plotkey (from the POINT table. A string concatenation of the values found in STATE, COUNTY, and PSU (in that order)) and 'S1'. DIMA source: From tblSoilPitHorizons - SoilKey. An automatically generated numerical string created at the time of new pit creation in the datetime format of YYMMDDHHMMSSR Where R is a random number between 1 and 9999. UNR source: UNR source: a concatenation of the plotkey (itself a concatenation of the date field (YYYYMMDD), the MLRA, a three digit number (000 to 999)) and the number '3'.

A unique alphanumeric string identifier for the plot. LMF source: SOILHORIZON - concatenation of STATE, COUNTY, and PSU in that order. DIMA source: tblSoilPits - PlotKey. UNR source: a concatenation of the date field (YYYYMMDD) the MLRA and a three digit number (000 to 999).

LMF source: SOILHORIZON - SURVEY. This field indicates the year of survey design; data collection may or may not have happened that year. A unique ID for a point includes the fields Survey, State, County, PSU, Point. DIMA source: tblSoilPits - DateRecorded. Year of the design is not available in the DIMA database. Year of DateRecorded is used instead. UNR source: Date. The year of the Date field.
The date that the pit was described. LMF source: POINTCOORDINATES - CAPDATE (UTC time). DIMA source: tblSoilPits - DateRecorded (local time). UNR source: Date (local time).

The units used to measure the depth of the soil pit. LMF source: 'in'. DIMA source: tblSoilPitHorizons - DepthMeasure. Pits having multiple units chosen were assigned the dominant units (unit choice error was assumed in this case). UNR source: None.
centimeters
inches. A unit of length in the (British) imperial and United States customary systems of measurement. It is equal to 1/12 foot and defined exactly as 25.4 mm.

A description of where the soil pit was located/dug. LMF source: None. Chapter 7 of the protocol states that pits should be located 'near the point where the two transects intersect'. DIMA source: tblSoilPits - PitDesc. UNR source: None.

The taxonomic description of the soil pedon. Description can be as general as an Order and as specific as a Family. LMF source: None. DIMA source: None. UNR source: Full soil description. Values have been cleaned and standardized.

cit:title.gco:CharacterString: Soil Survey Staff. 1999. Soil taxonomy: A basic system of soil classification for making and interpreting soil surveys. 2nd edition. Natural Resources Conservation Service. U.S. Department of Agriculture Handbook 436.

gfc:definition.gco:CharacterString: Any long form comments or notes that are associated with the completion of the soil description methodology. LMF source: None. DIMA source: tblSoilPits - Notes. UNR source: Any notes left over from the conversion process of the Full Soil Description field into a standard soil taxon description.
State data from the U.S. Census Bureau's Current State and Equivalent National Dataset.
Current state Federal Information Processing Series (FIPS) code.
National Standard Codes (ANSI INCITS 38-2009), Federal Information Processing Series (FIPS) - States/State Equivalents
Current Census region code.

Midwest
South
West

Current Census division code.
Puerto Rico and the Island Areas
New England
Middle Atlantic
East North Central
West North Central
South Atlantic
East South Central
West South Central
Mountain
Pacific
Current state GNIS code.

gfc:label.gco:CharacterString: INCITS 446:2008 (Geographic Names Information System (GNIS)), Identifying Attributes for Named Physical and Cultural Geographic Features (Except Roads and Highways) of the United States, Its Territories, Outlying Areas, and Freely Associated Areas, and the Waters of the Same to the Limit of the Twelve-Mile Statutory Zone

gfc:definition.gco:CharacterString: Current United States Postal Service state abbreviation.
Current state name.
National Standard Codes (ANSI INCITS 38-2009), Federal Information Processing Series (FIPS) - States/State Equivalents
Data associated with the transect establishment protocol(s) for that point.

A unique site identifier for each line/transect. LMF source: From the PINTERCEPT table. A string concatenation of the values found in STATE, COUNTY, and PSU (in that order). Additional concatenation of the transect the record is on ('NE','SE','NW', or 'SW'). DIMA source: From tblLines - LineKey. An automatically generated numerical string created at the time of new site creation in the datetime format of YYMMDDHHMMSSR Where R is a random number between 1 and 9999. UNR source: None
A unique alphanumeric string identifier for the plot. LMF source: PINTERCEPT - concatenation of STATE, COUNTY, and PSU in that order. DIMA source: tblLines - PlotKey. UNR source: None.

LMF source: PINTERCEPT - SURVEY. This field indicates the year of survey design; data collection may or may not have happened that year. A unique ID for a point includes the fields Survey, State, County, PSU, Point. DIMA source: tblLines - EstablishDate. Year of the design is not available in the DIMA database. Year of EstablishDate is used instead. UNR source: Date. The year of the Date field.
The date of the establishment of the plot. LMF source: POINTCOORDINATES - CAPDATE (UTC time). DIMA source: tblLPIHeader - MIN(FormDate) (local time). UNR source: None.
A label/identifier for the transect. LMF source: From transect crossing point, northeast='1a', southwest='1b', northwest='2a', southeast='2b'. DIMA source: tblLines - LineID. UNR source: None.

The direction (in degrees: 0-359) that the transect is laid out (or in LMF, the central point of crossing). LMF source: PINTERCEPT - TRANSECT (converted to degrees at plot center). DIMA source: tblLines - Azimuth. UNR source: None.
The measurement method of the transect azimuth. LMF source: 'magnetic'. DIMA source: tblLines - NorthType (1 = 'magnetic', 2 ='true'). UNR source: None.
The azimuth was recorded with magnetic north being the reference point for 0 degrees.
The azimuth was recorded with geodetic north being the reference point for 0 degrees, achieved using magnetic declination adjustment.
The length of the transect. LMF source: 75. DIMA source: tblLPIHeader - LineLengthAmount. UNR source: None.
The units used to for the transect length measurement. LMF source: 'ft'. DIMA source: 'm'. UNR source: None.
The GPS recorded Latitude of the start of the transect. Datum the same as recorded in the point - geo_datum field. LMF source: None. DIMA source: tblLines - LatitudeStart. UNR source: None.
Range Domain Minimum: -90. Range Domain Maximum: 90.
The GPS recorded Longitude of the start of the transect. Datum the same as recorded in the point - geo_datum field. LMF source: None. DIMA source: tblLines - LongitudeStart. UNR source: None.
Range Domain Minimum: -180. Range Domain Maximum: 180.
The GPS recorded elevation of the start of the transect. Units the same as in the point - elev_units field. LMF source: None. DIMA source: tblLines - ElevationStart. UNR source: None.
Range Domain Minimum: -1355. Range Domain Maximum: 29029.
The GPS recorded Latitude of the end of the transect. Datum the same as recorded in the point - geo_datum field. LMF source: None. DIMA source: tblLines - LatitudeEnd. UNR source: None.
Range Domain Minimum: -90. Range Domain Maximum: 90.
The GPS recorded Longitude of the end of the transect. Datum the same as recorded in the point - geo_datum field. LMF source: None. DIMA source: tblLines - LongitudeEnd. UNR source: None.
Range Domain Minimum: -180. Range Domain Maximum: 180.
The GPS recorded elevation of the end of the transect. Units the same as in the point - elev_units field. LMF source: None. DIMA source: tblLines - ElevationEnd. UNR source: None.
Range Domain Minimum: -1355. Range Domain Maximum: 29029.
latitude_start, longitude_start, elevation_start, latitude_end, longitude_end, elevation_end, and datum converted to the Geography data type. Horizontal Datum: NAD83 (srid 4269).
County data from the U.S. Census Bureau's Current County and Equivalent National Dataset.
County identifier; a concatenation of Current state FIPS code and county FIPS code.

The GEOID attribute is a concatenation of the state FIPS code followed by the county FIPS code. No spaces are allowed between the two codes. The State FIPS code is taken from "National Standard Codes (ANSI INCITS 38-2009), Federal Information Processing Series (FIPS) - States". The county FIPS code is taken from "National Standard Codes (ANSI INCITS 31-2009), Federal Information Processing Series (FIPS) - Counties/County Equivalents".
Current state Federal Information Processing Series (FIPS) code.
National Standard Codes (ANSI INCITS 38-2009), Federal Information Processing Series (FIPS) - States/State Equivalents
Current county Federal Information Processing Series (FIPS) code.
National Standard Codes (ANSI INCITS 31-2009), Federal Information Processing Series (FIPS) - Counties/County Equivalents.
Current county GNIS code.

INCITS 446:2008 (Geographic Names Information System (GNIS)), Identifying Attributes for Named Physical and Cultural Geographic Features (Except Roads and Highways) of the United States, Its Territories, Outlying Areas, and Freely Associated Areas, and the Waters of the Same to the Limit of the Twelve-Mile Statutory Zone.
Current county name.
National Standard Codes (ANSI INCITS 31-2009), Federal Information Processing Series (FIPS) - Counties/County Equivalents.
Current name and the translated legal/statistical area description for county.
The NAMELSAD attribute is a concatenation of the county name followed by the translated legal/statistical area description. No spaces are allowed between the two codes.
Current legal/statistical area description code for county.
Blank
City and Borough (suffix)
Borough (suffix)
Census Area (suffix)
County (suffix)
District (suffix)
Island (suffix)
Municipality (suffix)
Municipio (suffix)
Parish (suffix)
city (suffix)
The geometry for the county.
NRCS ecological sites which may be associated with a plot.

The identifier of a particular ecological community. For NRCS ecological sites, ecological site MLRA, ecological site LRU, ecological site number and ecological site state FIPS alpha code. Primary key for this table, it differs from the ecoid field in that ecological site type (range, forest, etc.) has been stripped. Any underscores and trailing numerical identifiers, if present, are also stripped.

The identifier of a particular ecological community. For NRCS ecological sites, it is the concatenated form of ecological site type, ecological site MLRA, ecological site LRU, ecological site number and ecological site state FIPS alpha code.

The descriptive name of a particular ecological community. For NRCS ecological sites, it is the concatenated form of three or six other fields. The actual fields that are concatenated together to form this name differ between range and forest ecological sites.
The ecological site type.
Range.
Forest
NRCS Major Land Resource Area ID associated with the ecological site.
Alphanumeric codes associated with each named Major Land Resource Area.

gfc:sourceIdentifier.gco:CharacterString: Appendix II. Area of LRRs and MLRAs, p. 655

cit:title.gco:CharacterString: United States Department of Agriculture, Natural Resources Conservation Service. 2006. Land Resource Regions and Major Land Resource Areas of the United States, theCaribbean, and the Pacific Basin. U.S. Department of Agriculture Handbook 296.

gfc:definition.gco:CharacterString: The subdivision code for a Major Land Resource Area (in the case that it is subdivided) associated with the ecological site.
The NRCS Land Resource Unit code associated with an ecological site.
The numeric identifier for an ecological site, within its LRU/MLRA.
Current United States Postal Service state abbreviation.
Two letter state abbreviations.

gfc:sourceIdentifier.gco:CharacterString: Appendix B: Two-Letter State and Possession Abbreviations, p. 55

gfc:definition.gco:CharacterString: The name/label/id of a user custom category or grouping of ecological sites above the ecological site scale but below the MLRA/LRU scale.
The type/category/name of the user custom ecological grouping.
USDA PLANTS database plant list.
A 3 to 7 digit alphanumeric code which uniquely identifies a genus, species, subspecies, etc. within the PLANTS database.
Identifies the taxonomic category in which the plant code falls (Genus, Species, Subspecies, Variety, Forma).

The scientific name associated with the plant in binomial nomenclature (without author). Scientific Names also sometimes will have trinomial or quadrinomial names associated with botanical nomenclature.
A common name for the plant (non-scientific).
The taxonomic Family to which the plant belongs. A sub-taxon of Order.

The plant life cycle length. Some plants have different Durations depending on environment or location, so a plant can have more than one value. Multiple values are reported in order of increasing longevity in nature.

gfc:sourceIdentifier.gco:CharacterString: Advanced Search and Download Notes. 3. Ecology: Duration.

gfc:definition.gco:CharacterString: The plant's entire life cycle, from seed to flower to seed, within a single growing season.
Plants which require two years to complete their life cycle.
Plants that persist for many growing seasons.
Refers to the shape, height, appearance, and form of growth of a plant species.

gfc:sourceIdentifier.gco:CharacterString: Advanced Search and Download Notes. 3. Ecology: Growth Habit

gfc:definition.gco:CharacterString: NRCS Growth Habit Codes and Definitions code list.

cit:title.gco:CharacterString: NRCS Growth Habit Codes and Definitions

cit:description.gco:CharacterString: A code list and definition set for Growth Habit in the USDA NRCS PLANTS database.

gfc:definition.gco:CharacterString: The status of a plants distribution in an area and its relationship to the historic populations within that area.

gfc:sourceIdentifier.gco:CharacterString: Advanced Search and Download. 3. Ecology: Native Status

gfc:definition.gco:CharacterString: Native Status and Native Status Jurisdiction code list in the form of "NativeStatusJurisdiction(NativeStatus)". Multiple jurisdictions are separated via a comma.

cit:title.gco:CharacterString: Native Status and Native Status Jurisdiction codes

cit:description.gco:CharacterString: We have broken the PFA into Native Status jurisdictions to try to improve our information about where plants are native. A plant that is native to any part of a Native Status jurisdiction (e.g., L48, the lower 48 states) is considered Native, even if some populations within that area are introduced. Thus the L48 Native Status value for smooth cordgrass (Spartina alterniflora) is N (Native) despite the existence of introduced populations on the West Coast. However, a plant like dandelion (Taraxacum officinale) is considered Native and Introduced since it has some infra-taxa that are native to L48 and some that are introduced there. Plants that do not occur in the PFA do not have Native Status values in PLANTS, though they may be cultivated or used as ornamentals within the PFA.

gfc:definition.gco:CharacterString: The indicator used before the genus name in the "scientific_name" field (×) which indicates that this plant is a hybrid of two genera.
The genus name of the plant, the first half of the scientific name in biniomial nomenclature. A taxonomic category that ranks below Family.
The indicator used before the species name in the "scientific_name" field (×) which indicates that this plant is a hybrid of two species.
The species name of the plant, the second half of the scientific name in biniomial nomenclature. A taxonomic category that ranks below Genus.
The indicator used before the subspecies name in the "scientific_name" field (ssp.) which indicates that this plant is a subspecies of another species.
The indicator used before the subspecies name (but after the subspecies prefix) in the "scientific_name" field (×) which indicates that this plant is a hybrid of two subspecies.
The subspecies name of the plant, the third portion of the scientific name in trinomial nomenclature. A taxonomic category that ranks below Species.
The indicator used before the subspecies name in the "scientific_name" field (var.) which indicates that this plant is a variety (varietas) of another species.
The indicator used before the variety name (but after the variety prefix) in the "scientific_name" field (×) which indicates that this plant is a hybrid of two varieties.

The variety name of the plant, the third portion of the scientific name in trinomial nomenclature. A taxonomic category that ranks below Subspecies. It is sometimes recommended that the subspecies rank should be used to recognize geographic distinctiveness, whereas the variety rank is appropriate if the taxon is seen throughout the geographic range of the species.
The indicator used before the form name in the "scientific_name" field (f.) which indicates that this plant is a form (forma) of another species/subspecies/variety.
The form name of the plant, the third or fourth portion of the scientific name in the botanical ternary naming system. A taxonomic category that ranks below Variety.

The author citation of the species. In botanical nomenclature, author citation refers to citing the person or group of people who validly published a botanical name, i.e. who first published the name while fulfilling the formal requirements as specified by the International Code of Nomenclature for algae, fungi, and plants (ICN). In cases where a species is no longer in its original generic placement (i.e. a new combination of genus and specific epithet), both the author(s) of the original genus placement and those of the new combination are given (the former in parentheses). In botany, it is customary (though not obligatory) to abbreviate author names according to a recognized list of standard abbreviations.
Botanist author name abbreviations.

cit:title.gco:CharacterString: Brummitt, R. K.; Powell, C. E., eds. (1992). Authors of Plant Names: a List of Authors of Scientific Names of Plants, with Recommended Standard Forms of their Names, Including Abbreviations. Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew.

cit:name.gco:CharacterString: List of botanists by author abbreviation (A)

gfc:definition.gco:CharacterString: The author citation of the trinomial taxon (subspecies, variety, etc.) in the ternary name of botanical nomenclature. In botanical nomenclature, author citation refers to citing the person or group of people who validly published a botanical name, i.e. who first published the name while fulfilling the formal requirements as specified by the International Code of Nomenclature for algae, fungi, and plants (ICN). In cases where a species is no longer in its original generic placement (i.e. a new combination of genus and specific epithet), both the author(s) of the original genus placement and those of the new combination are given (the former in parentheses). In botany, it is customary (though not obligatory) to abbreviate author names according to a recognized list of standard abbreviations.

The author citation of the quadrinomial taxon (e.g. form) in the ternary name of botanical nomenclature. In botanical nomenclature, author citation refers to citing the person or group of people who validly published a botanical name, i.e. who first published the name while fulfilling the formal requirements as specified by the International Code of Nomenclature for algae, fungi, and plants (ICN). In cases where a species is no longer in its original generic placement (i.e. a new combination of genus and specific epithet), both the author(s) of the original genus placement and those of the new combination are given (the former in parentheses). In botany, it is customary (though not obligatory) to abbreviate author names according to a recognized list of standard abbreviations.
In the case that a plant is a hybrid, gives the hybrid parents.
The distribution of the plant within U.S. States, Territories, and Protectorates; Canada Provinces and Territories; Greenland (Denmark), and St. Pierre and Miquelon (France).

gfc:sourceIdentifier.gco:CharacterString: Advanced Search and Download. 1. Distribution: State and Province

gfc:definition.gco:CharacterString: Distribution codes. State/Province identifiers occur as a comma separated list in the form of "CountryCode(State/Province)

cit:description.gco:CharacterString: The PLANTS database contains native and naturalized plants of the PLANTS Floristic Area (PFA), which consists of North America and all additional U.S. territories and protectorates. Vascular plant distributions are mapped at the state and province level, and by U.S. county. Our checklists for the non-vascular mosses, liverworts, hornworts, and lichens cover all of North America north of Mexico; no additional distribution data are currently available for these plants. Checklist and plant distribution by island and island group for the U.S. territories and protectorates in the PFA Pacific Basin area are in preparation but are not yet included at PLANTS. The total number of PFA accepted taxa at the rank of binomial and below is about 38,000. PLANTS also has about 5000 vascular plants that do not occur spontaneously (i.e., are not naturalized) in the PFA; these are selected if you choose Not in PLANTS Floristic Area. Most of these are of economic importance, and many of them are cultivated within the PFA.
